The IC50 of inhibition of125I-TGF-β·α2M* or125I-NGF·α2M* complex formation (mean ± S.D.) was determined in 5–8 independent experiments. 125I-TGF-β1 (1 ng) and125I-TGF-β1 (1 ng) preincubated with α2M* (10 μg) in the presence and absence of β125(41–65) (20 μm) at room temperature for 30 min were injected into lateral tail veins of mice anesthetized with ketamine as described previously (43LaMarre J. Hayes M. Wollenberg G. Hussaini I. Hall S. Gonias S. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 87: 39-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Blood samples (∼ 25 μl) were taken at 10 s, 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 60 min from the retroorbital venous plexus using heparinized hematocrit tubes. The radioactivity in the blood sample obtained at 10 s was taken as 100%. The experiments were performed in triplicate. To determine the potential binding site for α2M* on the TGF-β1 molecule, nine pentacosapeptides with amino acid sequences, which overlapped and covered the entire TGF-β1 molecule, were synthesized and tested for their abilities to inhibit125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M*, which had been activated by methylamine. Synthetic peptides with amino acid sequences derived from growth factors have successfully been used to identify the receptor binding sites of the growth factor molecules (42Huang S.S. Liu Q. Johnson F.E. Konish Y. Huang J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27155-27159Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 44Engström U. Engström A. Ernlund A. Westermark B. Heldin C.-H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 16581-16587Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These are typically composed of two or more distinct active site regions (42Huang S.S. Liu Q. Johnson F.E. Konish Y. Huang J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27155-27159Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 44Engström U. Engström A. Ernlund A. Westermark B. Heldin C.-H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 16581-16587Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Nondenaturing PAGE was used to analyze complex formation involving 125I-TGF-β1 and α2M*. In this system, the125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex co-migrates with α2M*, whereas free125I-TGF-β1 does not migrate into the separating gel because of its basicity (10Huang S.S. O'Grady P. Huang J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 1535-1541Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). As shown in Fig.1, at a concentration of 375 μm, pentacosapeptides β125(21–45), β125(31–55), β125(41–65), and β125(51–75) with amino acid sequences corresponding to amino acid residues 21–45, 31–55, 41–65, and 51–75 of TGF-β1, respectively, effectively inhibited the formation of 125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex. The TGF-β1-derived peptides, which covered other regions of the TGF-β1 molecule, were not active in blocking 125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation. These included β125(61–85), β125(71–95), β125(81–105) (see Fig. 1), β125(1–25), and β125(88–112) (data not shown). The inhibitory pentacosapeptides blocked125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation in a concentration-dependent manner (Fig.2). The IC50 values were estimated to be 30 ± 7 μm for β125(21–45) (n = 6), 40 ± 20 μm for β125(31–55) (n = 6), 7 ± 3 μm for β125(41–65) (n = 8), and 60 ± 10 μm for β125(51–75) (n = 6). All effective inhibitory peptides contain tryptophan residues (Trp-52 or Trp-30/Trp-32). However, the peptide containing residues 41–65 showed the most potent inhibitory activity.Figure 2Inhibition of the125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation by synthetic TGF-β1 pentacosapeptides containing Trp-52 and Trp-30/Trp-32. 5 μg of α2M* was reacted with 1 ng of 125I-TGF-β1 in the presence of various concentrations of β125(31–55), β125(41–65), β125(51–75), and β125(21–45). A, after 30 min at room temperature, the reaction mixture was analyzed with 5% nondenaturing PAGE and autoradiography. The arrow andarrowhead indicate the location of the125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex and dye front, respectively. B, the intensity of the125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex was quantitated using a PhosphorImager. The intensity of the125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formed in the absence of TGF-β1 pentacosapeptides was taken as 100%.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To further define the biological relevance of the peptide inhibition of125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation in a whole-animal system, we determined the plasma clearance of free 125I-TGF-β1 and125I-TGF-β1 preincubated with α2M* in the presence and absence of β125(41–65) in mice. Intravenously injected-free 125I-TGF-β1 and125I-TGF-β·α2M* complexes are known to be cleared from the circulation at different rates (half-time =t 1/2) in mice (43LaMarre J. Hayes M. Wollenberg G. Hussaini I. Hall S. Gonias S. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 87: 39-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Whether β125(41–65) inhibits the complex formation of 125I-TGF-β and α2M*, thet 1/2 of 125I-TGF-β preincubated with α2M* in the presence of β125(41–65) should be similar to that of free 125I-TGF-β1. As shown in Fig.3, this proved to be the case witht 1/2 = 1.6 ± 0.1 min essentially identical to that of free 125I-TGF-β1. Thet 1/2 of 125I-TGF-β1preincubated with α2M* in the absence of β125(41–65) was 3.3 ± 0.1 min, which was comparable to the reported value for the125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex (43LaMarre J. Hayes M. Wollenberg G. Hussaini I. Hall S. Gonias S. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 87: 39-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). This result indicates that β125(41–65) inhibits the complex formation of 125I-TGF-β1and α2M* in a standard whole-animal model. As shown in Fig. 2, β125(41–65), which contained Trp-52 in the middle, was more effective in inhibiting125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation than β125(31–55) and β125(51–75), which contained Trp-52 near the C terminus and N terminus, respectively. This finding implies that Trp-52 may play a role in the inhibitory activities of the peptides. To test this possibility, we synthesized pentacosapeptides β125(41–65)W52A, in which Trp-52 was replaced with alanine, scrambled β125(41–65), in which the amino acid sequence of residues 41–65 was random, and β125(65–41), which contained the reversed sequence of residues 41–65. They had no effect on125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation (data not shown). To further define the role of Trp-52 in the inhibitory activities of various synthetic TGF-β peptides, we determined the effects of decapeptides β110(49–58), β210(49–58), and β310(49–58) on125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation. Both β110(49–58) and β210(49–58) contained Trp-52, whereas β310(49–58) possessed Arg-52 instead. As shown in Fig. 4, both β110(49–58) and β210(49–58) had equal potency in inhibiting125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation with IC50 values of ∼200 ± 20 μm (n = 5) and 190 ± 25 μm (n = 5), respectively. In contrast, β310(49–58) was inactive. Increasing the peptide length in β325(41–65) did not improve its inability to block125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation (data not shown). Replacement of Trp-52 with alanine in β110(49–58) abolished the inhibitory activity. Replacement of Asp-55 with alanine in β110(49–58) enhanced the inhibitory activity (IC50 = 100 ± 10 μm), but the replacement of Ser-53 with alanine in β110(49–58)S53A diminished the inhibitory activity (IC50 = >1000 μm). These results suggest that Trp-52 is important for the inhibitory activities of synthetic TGF-β peptides containing Trp-52, and that alteration of the amino acid sequence near residue 52 also affects activity in some instances. Because synthetic growth factor peptide antagonists or inhibitors often contain active-site amino acid residues (42Huang S.S. Liu Q. Johnson F.E. Konish Y. Huang J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27155-27159Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 44Engström U. Engström A. Ernlund A. Westermark B. Heldin C.-H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 16581-16587Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we hypothesized that the Trp-52 residue is involved in the high affinity binding of TGF-β1 and TGF-β2 to α2M*. To test this hypothesis, we determined the affinity of125I-labeled TGF-β3(125I-TGF-β3) binding to α2M*. If the Trp-52 residue is involved in the high affinity binding of TGF-β1 and TGF-β2 to α2M*,125I-TGF-β3 should show weaker binding to α2M* than TGF-β1 and TGF-β2, because it has an arginine residue instead of tryptophan at position 52. As shown in Fig. 5,125I-TGF-β3 bound to α2M* in a concentration-dependent manner. Scatchard plot analysis of this binding data revealed an apparent K d of 400 nm of 125I-TGF-β3 binding to α2M*. In the control experiment, the apparentK d of 125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M* was estimated to be ∼54 nm. This result is comparable to the reported K d value of125I-TGF-β1 binding (21Gonias S.L. LaMarre J. Crookston K.P. Webb D.J. Wolf B.B. Lopes M.B. Moses H.L. Hayes M.A. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1994; 737: 273-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). This finding shows that TGF-β3 binds to α2M* with an affinity lower than those of TGF-β1 and TGF-β2. TGF-β2 has been shown to bind to α2M* with an affinity 10-fold higher than that of TGF-β1 (21Gonias S.L. LaMarre J. Crookston K.P. Webb D.J. Wolf B.B. Lopes M.B. Moses H.L. Hayes M.A. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1994; 737: 273-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). Because TGF-β1 isoforms share ∼70% amino acid sequence homology, it is possible that amino acid residues other than Trp-52 also contribute to the high affinity binding of TGF-β1 to α2M*. To test this possibility, we prepared the TGF-β1 mutant TGF-β1W52A in which Trp-52 was replaced by alanine by site-directed mutagenesis as described previously (41Huang S.S. Zhou M. Johnson F.E. Shieh H.-S. Huang J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 27754-27758Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar) and then determined the effect of 200-fold excess TGF-β1W52A on125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M*. As shown in Fig. 6, lanes 2 and3, unlabeled TGF-β3 and TGF-β1W52A only partially inhibited binding (∼15–25%) of 125I-TGF-β1 to α2M* even at 200-fold excess concentration. In contrast, unlabeled TGF-β1 completely blocked125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M* at a 200-fold excess concentration (Fig. 6, lane 1). This result suggests that Trp-52 is important for high affinity binding of TGF-β1 to α2M*. TGF-β and other growth factors/cytokines/hormones compete for binding to α2M* (28Gonias S.L. Carmichael A. Meltenburg J.M. Roadmap D.W. Irvin W.P. Webb D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 5826-5831Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar), suggesting that the binding site(s) in α2M for these proteins may be the same or overlapping. The lack of homology of amino acid sequences and differences in three-dimensional structures among these growth factors/cytokines/hormones further suggests that they may bind to α2M via a mechanism that is dependent on surface topology, e.g. specific hydrophobic regions in the molecules. Because NGF is known to compete with TGF-β for binding to α2M* (28Gonias S.L. Carmichael A. Meltenburg J.M. Roadmap D.W. Irvin W.P. Webb D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 5826-5831Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar), we determined the effect of the synthetic TGF-β peptides on 125I-NGF binding to α2M*. As shown in Fig. 7, β125(41–65), β110(49–58), and β210(49–58) inhibited 125I-NGF binding to α2M* with IC50 values of 35 ± 10 μm (n = 5), 250 ± 15 μm (n = 5), and 260 ± 20 μm (n = 5), respectively. The pentacosapeptide β125(21–45), which contained Trp-30/Trp-32, inhibited complex formation of125I-NGF and α2M* with an IC50 of 300 ± 20 μm (n = 5). β110(49–58)W52A and β310(49–58) were inactive in inhibiting complex formation of 125I-TGF-β1 and α2M*. These results suggest that although these synthetic TGF-β peptides are less active inhibitors of 125I-NGF binding to α2M* than those of125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M*, the residue Trp-52 is essential in both cases. In this study, we present several lines of evidence suggesting that the residue Trp-52 is involved in the high affinity binding of TGF-β1 to α2M*. Such evidence include: 1) among nine synthetic pentacosapeptides whose amino acid sequences overlap and span the entire TGF-β1 molecule, β125(41–65), which contains Trp-52 in the middle of the peptide, exhibited the most potent activity in inhibiting125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M* as determined by nondenaturing PAGE and by plasma clearance, 2) β225(41–65) was as effective as β125(41–65) in blocking125I-TGF-β1·α2M* complex formation, whereas β325(41–65), which lacks Trp-52, scrambled β125(41–65), which contains the scrambled amino acid sequence of residues 41–65, and β125(65–41), which contains the reversed sequence of residues 41–65, were inactive, 3) β110(49–58) and β210(49–58), both of which contain Trp-52, effectively blocked 125I-TGF-β1 binding to α2M*, whereas β325(49–58), which contains Arg-52 instead of Trp-52, was not active, 4) the replacement of Trp-52 with alanine completely abolished the activities of TGF-β1 and TGF-β2 peptides containing Trp-52, 5) 125I-TGF-β3, which lacks Trp-52, weakly bound to α2M* with an apparentK d of ∼400 nm, and 6) unlabeled TGF-β3 and the mutant TGF-β1W52A were less effective in blocking 125I-TGF-β1binding to α2M* than unlabeled TGF-β1. The residue Trp-52 appears to be critical for high affinity binding of TGF-β1 and TGF-β2 to α2M*. We also show that Trp-30/Trp-32 in residues 21–45 may be involved in the low affinity binding of TGF-β3 and TGF-β1W52A to α2M*. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1, also known as NKX2.1 and T/EBP), a transcription factor belonging to the NKX-2 family of homeodomain-containing genes, plays an essential role in the organogenesis of the thyroid gland, lung, and ventral forebrain. Nestin is an intermediate filament protein strongly expressed in multipotential neuroepithelial stem cells and rapidly down-regulated during postnatal life. Here we show that stable fibroblastic clones expressing TTF-1 acquire a phenotype reminiscent of neuroepithelial cells in culture and up-regulate the endogenous nestin gene. TTF-1 transactivates in HeLa and NIH3T3 cells a reporter gene driven by a central nervous system-specific enhancer element from the second intron of the rat nestin gene, where it recognizes a DNA-binding site (NestBS) whose sequence resembles a nuclear hormone/cAMP-responsive element very different from canonical TTF-1 binding sites. Nuclear extracts from the head of mouse embryos form a retarded complex with NestBS of the same mobility of the extracts obtained from TTF1-expressing clones, which is either abolished or supershifted in the presence of two different antibodies recognizing the TTF-1 protein. Thus, the neuroepithelial marker nestin is a direct central nervous system-specific target gene of TTF-1, leading to the hypothesis that it might be the effector through which TTF-1 plays its role in the organogenesis of the forebrain.

Thrombin possesses two positively charged surface domains, termed exosites, that orient substrates and inhibitors for reaction with the enzyme. Because the exosites also allosterically modulate thrombin's activity, we set out to determine whether the structure or function of the exosites changes when thrombin forms complexes with antithrombin, heparin cofactor II, or α1-antitrypsin (M358R), serpins that utilize both, one, or neither of the exosites, respectively. Using a hirudin-derived peptide to probe the integrity of exosite 1, no binding was detected when thrombin was complexed with heparin cofactor II or α1-antitrypsin (M358R), and the peptide exhibited a 55-fold lower affinity for the thrombin-antithrombin complex than for thrombin. Bound peptide or HD-1, an exosite 1-binding DNA aptamer, was displaced from thrombin by each of the three serpins. Thrombin binding to fibrin also was abrogated when the enzyme was complexed with serpins. These data reveal that, regardless of the initial mode of interaction, the function of exosite 1 is lost when thrombin is complexed by serpins. In contrast, the integrity of exosite 2 is largely retained when thrombin is complexed by serpins, because interaction with heparin or an exosite 2-directed DNA aptamer was only modestly altered. The disorganization of exosite 1 that occurs when thrombin is complexed by serpins is consistent with results of protease sensitivity studies and crystallographic analysis of a homologous enzyme-serpin complex. To prevent excessive clotting, the activity of thrombin must be tightly regulated (1Colman R.W. Clowes A.W. George J.N. Marder V.J. Colman R.W. Hirsh J. Marder V.J. Clowes A.W. George J.N. Hemostasis and Thrombosis. Basic Principles and Clinical Practice. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Philadelphia2001: 3-16Google Scholar). Down-regulation of thrombin activity is mediated by two serpins, antithrombin and heparin cofactor II, which form 1:1 stoichiometric complexes with thrombin (2Bock S.C. Colman R.W. Hirsh J. Marder V.J. Clowes A.W. George J.N. Hemostasis and Thrombosis. Basic Principles and Clinical Practice. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Philadelphia2001: 321-334Google Scholar). Another inhibitory mechanism involves thrombomodulin, a thrombin receptor found on the surface of vascular endothelial cells. Once bound to thrombomodulin, thrombin undergoes a specificity change that converts it from a procoagulant enzyme into one that initiates an anticoagulant pathway by activating protein C (3Esmon C.T. Hoffman R. Benz E.J. Shattil S.J. Furie B. Cohen H.J. Silberstein L.E. McGlave P. Hematology. Basic Principles and Practice. Churchill Livingstone, New York2000: 1714-1824Google Scholar). Selective interactions of thrombin with its substrates, cofactors, and inhibitors reflect structural characteristics unique to thrombin. These structural features include two surface loops that limit access to the active site by protruding over the active site cleft. In addition, thrombin possesses two positively charged domains, termed exosites, located on opposite poles of the thrombin molecule (4Stubbs M.T. Bode W. Thromb. Res. 1993; 69: 1-58Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (443) Google Scholar, 5Bode W. Turk D. Karshikov A. Protein Sci. 1992; 1: 426-471Crossref PubMed Scopus (646) Google Scholar, 6Di Cera E. Dang Q.D. Ayala Y. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 1997; 53: 701-730Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). The principal role of exosite 1 is to bind substrates, cofactors, and inhibitors and orient them for optimal interaction with the active site. This exosite, which also is known as the fibrinogen recognition site (7Fenton J.W.I. Olson T.A. Zabinski M.P. Wilner G.D. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 7106-7112Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar), interacts with negatively charged domains on fibrinogen, the thrombin receptor, hirudin, thrombomodulin, and heparin cofactor II. In contrast, the other exosite, which is designated exosite 2, binds heparin, dermatan sulfate, and chondroitin sulfate, glycosaminoglycans that promote thrombin's interactions with serine protease inhibitors and thrombomodulin. In addition to mediating thrombin's interactions with its substrates and inhibitors, the exosites also modulate thrombin's activity. By binding to exosite 1, in a concerted interaction that also involves exosite 2, thrombomodulin abolishes the procoagulant activity of thrombin by hindering its reaction with fibrinogen, factors V and VIII, and the thrombin receptor (8Esmon C.T. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 946-955Crossref PubMed Scopus (358) Google Scholar, 9Knobe K.E. Berntsdotter A. Shen L. Morser J. Dahlback B. Villoutreix B.O. Nature. 2000; 404: 518-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar). Coincidentally, thrombin's interaction with thrombomodulin induces allosteric changes at the active site of the enzyme (11Duffy E.J. Angliker H. Le Bonniec B.F. Stone S.R. Biochem. J. 1997; 321: 361-365Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar, 12Esmon C.T. Biochim. Biophys. Fibrinolysis Proteolysis. 1999; 13: 72-77Crossref Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Interactions at exosite 2 also modulate the structure and function of the active site of thrombin (14Fredenburgh J.C. Stafford A.R. Weitz J.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 25493-25499Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 15Liu L.W. Ye J. Johnson A.E. Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Exosite 2 contributes to the inactivation of thrombin by antithrombin and heparin cofactor II by serving as a heparin-binding site, thereby promoting heparin-mediated bridging of the enzyme to the inhibitor (16Olson S.T. Björk I. Semin. Thromb. Hemost. 1994; 20: 373-409Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar,17Tollefsen D.M. Thromb. Haemost. 1995; 74: 1209-1214Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Exosite 1 also plays an important role in the interaction of thrombin with heparin cofactor II. Binding of heparin or dermatan sulfate to heparin cofactor II disrupts the intramolecular interaction of the NH2-terminal domain, allowing it to bridge to exosite 1 on thrombin (17Tollefsen D.M. Thromb. Haemost. 1995; 74: 1209-1214Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 18Liaw P.C. Austin R.C. Fredenburgh J.C. Stafford A.R. Weitz J.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 27597-27604Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The exosites are not essential for thrombin inactivation, however, because α1-antitrypsin Pittsburgh, a naturally occurring variant with its reactive site P1 residue, Met-358, replaced with Arg (M358R), has no requirement for interaction with either exosite (19Owen M.C. Brennan S.O. Lewis J.H. Carrell R.W. N. Engl. J. Med. 1983; 309: 694-698Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar, 20Bischoff R. Speck D. Lepage P. Delatre L. Ledoux C. Brown S.W. Roitsch C. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 3464-3472Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). To determine whether the integrity of exosite 1 on thrombin is compromised when the enzyme is complexed by serpins, we first compared the affinity of hirudin54–65, a peptide that binds exclusively to exosite 1 on thrombin, for active thrombin with that for thrombin complexed by the various serpins. Titration of a fluorescein derivative of hirudin54–65 with thrombin produced a saturable decrease in fluorescence intensity (Fig.2). Fluorescein-hirudin54–65bound thrombin with a Kd of 41 nm, a value consistent with that reported previously (15Liu L.W. Ye J. Johnson A.E. Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 23632-23636Google Scholar, 21Bock P.E. Olson S.T. Bjork I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 19837-19845Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Although saturable binding also was observed when fluorescein-hirudin54–65 was titrated with thrombin-antithrombin complexes, the affinity of the interaction was 55-fold weaker than that with thrombin (Kd value of 2270 nm). Bock et al. (21Bock P.E. Olson S.T. Bjork I. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 19837-19845Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) also demonstrated reduced affinity of fluorescein-hirudin54–65 for the thrombin-antithrombin complex. In their study, saturable binding of fluorescein-hirudin54–65 to the thrombin-antithrombin complex could not be demonstrated, suggesting that theKd value was greater than 5 μm. In contrast to the results obtained with thrombin-antithrombin complexes, when thrombin-heparin cofactor II or thrombin- α1-antitrypsin M358R complexes were titrated with fluorescein-hirudin54–65, no binding was detected (Fig.2). These findings suggest that the structure of thrombin may differ depending on the serpin with which it is complexed. To further explore this concept, the binding of fluorescein-hirudin54–65 to thrombin was monitored in real time as the sample was titrated with each of the three serpins. As illustrated in Fig.3, addition of thrombin to fluorescein-hirudin54–65 produced a ∼12% decrease in fluorescence intensity, and this value was unchanged upon the addition of 400 nm heparin. When 100 nm antithrombin was added, the fluorescence intensity rapidly returned to a value approaching that obtained with fluorescein-hirudin54–65alone, suggesting that antithrombin reduced the amount of fluorescein-hirudin54–65 bound to thrombin. When parallel experiments were performed with heparin cofactor II and α1-antitrypsin M358R, similar results were obtained. Based on fluorescence intensity values recorded after serpin addition, heparin cofactor II or α1-antitrypsin M358R displaced 99% of fluorescein-hirudin54–65 from thrombin, whereas only 92% displacement was observed with antithrombin. Reduced displacement with antithrombin relative to the other two serpins is consistent with the observation that fluorescein-hirudin54–65 retains affinity for the thrombin-antithrombin complex, albeit much less than that for thrombin (Fig. 2). To determine whether formation of a covalent complex between thrombin and a non-serpin, active-site-directed inhibitor is sufficient to alter the integrity of exosite 1, FPRck (500 nm) was added to a cuvette containing fluorescein-hirudin54–65 and thrombin (not shown). In contrast to the results with the serpins, chloromethyl ketone addition had no effect on fluorescence intensity, indicating that it did not displace fluorescein-hirudin54–65 from exosite 1. These results suggest that reduced binding of exosite 1-directed ligands to thrombin complexed by serpins cannot be explained solely by covalent complex formation at the active site of the enzyme. Displacement experiments also were performed using an exosite 1-directed DNA aptamer, HD-1, in place of the hirudin54–65peptide (22Bock L. Griffin L.C. Latham J.A. Vermaas E.H. Toole J.J. Nature. 1992; 355: 564-566Crossref PubMed Scopus (2096) Google Scholar). The fluorescent derivative of HD-1 binds thrombin with aKd value of 235 nm, producing an ∼11% increase in fluorescence intensity (Fig.4, inset). Under the conditions of the displacement experiment, addition of 100 nm thrombin to 20 nm fluorescein-HD-1 resulted in a ∼3.5% increase in fluorescence intensity (Fig. 4). When 500 nm antithrombin, heparin cofactor II, or α1-antitrypsin M358R was added in the presence of 4 nm heparin, the fluorescence intensity rapidly returned to a value similar to that of unbound fluorescein-HD-1. These results are in agreement with those obtained with hirudin54–65, suggesting that exosite 1 function is compromised when thrombin is complexed by serpins. The observation that antithrombin addition results in complete displacement of fluorescein-HD-1, but not of fluorescein-hirudin54–65, may reflect differing binding interactions between the two ligands and thrombin. To determine whether the interaction of exosite 1 with physiological ligands also was altered when thrombin was complexed with serpins, we compared the binding of thrombin-serpin complexes to fibrin with that of thrombin (Fig. 5). Samples containing 50 nm125I-thrombin or125I-thrombin-serpin complexes and 0–10 μmfibrinogen were clotted with Atroxin. After 60-min incubation, clots were compacted by centrifugation and unbound 125I-thrombin or 125I-thrombin-serpin complex in the supernatants was quantified by counting aliquots for radioactivity. Under these conditions, thrombin bound fibrin with a Kd value of 1.6 μm, a value comparable to that reported previously (31Hogg P.J. Bock P.E. Thromb. Haemost. 1997; 77: 424-433Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 32Binnie C.G. Lord S.T. Blood. 1993; 81: 3186-3192Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, no binding of thrombin-serpin complexes was observed. Thus, the loss of function of exosite 1 observed with synthetic ligands extends to physiological ligands such as fibrin. As a second macromolecular probe of exosite 1, binding of a thrombin-specific antibody to thrombin and thrombin serpin complexes was examined. Autoantibody D is a human-derived antibody that binds to thrombin to exosite 1, as demonstrated by the lack of binding to thrombin variants with mutations in this region (29Wu Q. Picard V. Aiach M. Sadler J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3725-3730Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Using protein G-agarose to extract thrombin-antibody complexes, autoantibody D bound 66% of 125I-thrombin (not shown). The antibody recovered 11, 10, and 13% of the radioactivity of thrombin-antithrombin, thrombin-heparin cofactor II, or thrombin-α1-antitrypsin M358R complexes, respectively. Thus, reactivity with the exosite 1-directed antibody was greatly reduced when thrombin was complexed with serpins. Havin

There is accumulating evidence that the specificity of the transduction cascades activated by G protein-coupled receptors cannot solely depend on the nature of the coupled G protein. To identify additional structural determinants, we studied two metabotropic glutamate (mGlu) receptors, the mGlu2 and mGlu7 receptors, that are both coupled to Go proteins but are known to affect different effectors in neurons. Thus, the mGlu2 receptor selectively blocks N- and L-type Ca2+ channels via a protein kinase C-independent pathway, whereas the mGlu7 receptor selectively blocks P/Q-type Ca2+ channels via a protein kinase C-dependent pathway, and both effects are pertussis toxin-sensitive. We examined the role of the C-terminal domain of these receptors in this coupling. Chimeras were constructed by exchanging the C terminus of these receptors and transfected into neurons. Different chimeric receptors bearing the C terminus of mGlu7 receptor blocked selectively P/Q-type Ca2+ channels, whereas chimeras bearing the C terminus of mGlu2 receptor selectively blocked N- and L-type Ca2+ channels. These results show that the C terminus of mGlu2 and mGlu7 receptors is a key structural determinant that allows these receptors to select a specific signaling pathway in neurons. Different chimeric receptors bearing the C terminus of mGlu7 receptor blocked selectively P/Q-type Ca2+ channels, whereas chimeras bearing the C terminus of mGlu2 receptor selectively blocked N- and L-type Ca2+ channels. G protein-coupled receptor metabotropic glutamate protein kinase C dihydroxyphenyl glycine green fluorescent protein dl-aminophosphonobutyrate inositol phosphate The physiological actions of most neurotransmitters are mediated by activation of both ionotropic and G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs1 or metabotropic receptors). For instance, the metabotropic receptors activated by the excitatory neurotransmitter, glutamate, play crucial roles in synaptic plasticity, neurotoxicity, as well as neuroprotection. These effects result from a large variety of regulations such as direct mediation of glutaminergic synaptic transmission or modulation of neurotransmitter release or membrane excitability (1Pin J.P. Bockaert J. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1995; 5: 342-349Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). Transduction of extracellular signals to intracellular responses via GPCR includes stimulation of the receptor, activation of a trimeric G protein, and subsequent mobilization of specific effectors. The regions of the receptor involved in G protein activation have been studied extensively (2Bourne H.R. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1997; 9: 134-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (527) Google Scholar). The second intracellular loop of mGlu receptors is responsible for the selective recognition of the G protein α subunit (3Pin J.P. Joly C. Heinemann S.F. Bockaert J. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 342-348Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar, 4Gomeza J. Joly C. Kuhn R. Knopfel T. Bockaert J. Pin J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 2199-2205Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), whereas all other receptor intracellular segments control the coupling efficacy (4Gomeza J. Joly C. Kuhn R. Knopfel T. Bockaert J. Pin J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 2199-2205Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). Eight genes encoding mGlu receptors have been identified and classified into three groups, according to their sequence and intracellular signaling. The group I mGlu receptors (mGlu1 and -5) are coupled to Gq-like proteins and activate phospholipase C, whereas the group II (mGlu2 and -3) and group III (mGlu4 and -6–8) receptors are coupled to Gi/Go proteins and inhibit cAMP formation (5Prezeau L. Carrette J. Helpap B. Curry K. Pin J.P. Bockaert J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1994; 45: 570-577PubMed Google Scholar, 6Conn P.J. Pin J.P. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 1997; 37: 205-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (2727) Google Scholar). The signaling cascades of mGlu receptors seem, however, to be far more complex than these consensual pathways. These receptors can indeed activate cGMP phosphodiesterase (7Nawy S. Jahr C.E. Nature. 1990; 346: 269-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (363) Google Scholar), phospholipase D (8Boss V. Conn P.J. J. Neurochem. 1992; 59: 2340-2343Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar), phospholipase A2 (9Dumuis A. Pin J.P. Oomagari K. Sebben M. Bockaert J. Nature. 1990; 347: 182-184Crossref PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar), and mitogen-activated protein kinase cascades (10Ferraguti F. Baldani-Guerra B. Corsi M. Nakanishi S. Corti C. Eur. J. Neurosci. 1999; 11: 2073-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar). Through these pathways, the mGlu receptors can control ionic channel activities (11Kammermeier P.J. Ikeda S.R. Neuron. 1999; 22: 819-829Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 12Fagni L. Chavis P. Ango F. Bockaert J. Trends Neurosci. 2000; 23: 80-88Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar, 13Charpak S. Gähwiler B.H. Do K.Q. Knöpfel T. Nature. 1990; 347: 765-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (331) Google Scholar). Thus it is remarkable that mGlu receptors activating the same group of G proteins inhibit distinct Ca2+ channel subtypes (14Sahara Y. Westbrook G.L. J. A. 1999; 96: 10899-10904Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar) have shown that the same G protein βγ subunit combination can inhibit different Ca2+ channel subtypes and vice versa. The mGlu receptors have even been shown to activate directly effectors and generate cellular responses independently of G protein activation (25Heuss C. Gerber U. Trends Neurosci. 2000; 23: 469-475Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). This large variety of mGlu receptor actions together with the limited number of functional G protein subunit combinations (26Morris A.J. Malbon C.C. Physiol. Rev. 1999; 79: 1373-1430Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar) suggest that the signaling cascade specificity of a given GPCR cannot arise solely from the nature of the activated G protein. The aim of the present study was to examine whether receptor structural determinants are involved in the specificity of GPCR signaling. To address this issue we studied two GPCRs, the mGlu2 and mGlu7 receptor subtypes. These receptors are both coupled to Gi/Go proteins but trigger different second messenger cascades, in cultured cerebellar granule cells. Thus, both receptors activate a pertussis toxin-sensitive G protein, but the mGlu2 receptor selectively blocks N- and L-type Ca2+ channels (15Chavis P. Fagni L. Bockaert J. Lansman J.B. Neuropharmacology. 1995; 34: 929-937Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar), whereas the mGlu7 receptor blocks the P/Q-type Ca2+channels (27Perroy J. Prézeau L. De Waard M. Shigemoto R. Bockaert J. Fagni L. J. Neurosci. 2000; 20: 7896-7904Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Moreover, the effect of the mGlu7 (27Perroy J. Prézeau L. De Waard M. Shigemoto R. Bockaert J. Fagni L. J. Neurosci. 2000; 20: 7896-7904Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) but not mGlu2 (15Chavis P. Fagni L. Bockaert J. Lansman J.B. Neuropharmacology. 1995; 34: 929-937Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar) receptor is PKC-dependent. To examine the possible role of the C-terminal intracellular domain of these receptors in specifying their transduction cascade, the coupling to N- and L- or P/Q-type Ca2+ channels of chimeric receptors bearing either the C-terminal domain of mGlu2 or that of mGlu7 was examined in cultured cerebellar granule cells. We found that the C terminus of the mGlu7 receptor was necessary and sufficient to select a PKC-dependent inhibitory pathway specific to the P/Q-type Ca2+ channel, whereas the C terminus of the mGlu2 receptor was necessary and sufficient for a PKC-independent inhibition of N- and L-type Ca2+ channels. These findings reveal a new role of the C terminus of mGlu2 and mGlu7 receptors in specifying their respective transduction cascades downstream from the G protein activation. Primary cultures of cerebellar cells were prepared as described previously (28Van Vliet B.J. Sebben M. Dumuis A. Gabrion J. Bockaert J. Pin J.P. J. Neurochem. 1989; 52: 1229-1239Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). Briefly, 1-week-old newborn mice were decapitated and the cerebellum dissected. The tissue was then gently triturated using fire-polished Pasteur pipettes, and the homogenate was centrifuged at 500 rpm. The pellet was resuspended and plated in tissue culture dishes previously coated with poly-l-ornithine. Cells were maintained in a 1:1 mixture of Dulbecco's minimum essential medium and F-12 nutrient (Life Technologies, Inc.) supplemented with glucose (30 mm), glutamine (2 mm), sodium bicarbonate (3 mm), HEPES buffer (5 mm), decomplemented fetal calf serum (10%), and 25 mm KCl to improve neuronal survival. One-week-old cultures contained 1 × 106 cells. The chimeric receptors were constructed as follows. The mGlu2/7 and mGlu7/2 chimeras were obtained by exchanging the C-terminal region proximal to the seventh transmembrane domain of the mGlu7a receptor (beginning with HPELNVQKRK) with its homologous mGlu2 receptor domain (beginning with QPQKNVVSHR) (see Fig. 2), using the polymerase chain reaction overlap method (29Ho S.N. Hunt H.D. Horton R.M. Pullen J.K. Pease L.R. Gene (Amst.). 1989; 77: 51-59Crossref PubMed Scopus (6829) Google Scholar). The construction of the mGlu1/2 chimera containing the N-terminal extracellular domain of the mGlu1 receptor and the heptahelical and C-terminal regions of the mGlu2 receptor has been described previously (30Caroll F. Stolle A. Beart P.M. Voerste A. Brabet I. Mauler F. Joly C. Antonicek H. Bockaert J. Muller T. Pin J.P. Prézeau L. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 59: 965-973Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). The mGlu1/2/7 chimera was constructed by replacing the fragment encoding the 3′-half of the mGlu1/2 chimera by that of the mGlu2/7 chimera, using the BsrGI and XbaI restriction sites of the mGlu2 receptor heptahelical domain coding sequence and the pRK5 poly-linker, respectively. The wild type and chimeric receptors were tested for their coupling to G protein using the method that we described previously (31Parmentier M.L. Joly C. Restituito S. Bockaert J. Grau Y. Pin J.P. Mol. Pharmacol. 1998; 53: 778-786Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Briefly, inositol phosphate (IP) accumulation was measured in HEK-293 cells co-transfected with the tested receptor and a recombinant G protein. The mGlu1 receptor was co-transfected with a GHQ protein, whereas the mGlu2, mGlu7a, mGlu2/7, mGlu7/2, mGlu1/2, and mGlu1/2/7 receptors were co-transfected with a chimeric Gqi9 protein. In the Gqi9 chimeric protein, the C-terminal 9 residues of the G protein αq subunit were replaced by those of the G protein αi2 subunit, enabling the coupling of the receptors to phospholipase C (4Gomeza J. Joly C. Kuhn R. Knopfel T. Bockaert J. Pin J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 2199-2205Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 30Caroll F. Stolle A. Beart P.M. Voerste A. Brabet I. Mauler F. Joly C. Antonicek H. Bockaert J. Muller T. Pin J.P. Prézeau L. Mol. Pharmacol. 2001; 59: 965-973Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar, 31Parmentier M.L. Joly C. Restituito S. Bockaert J. Grau Y. Pin J.P. Mol. Pharmacol. 1998; 53: 778-786Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Albani-Torregrossa S. Joly C. Robbe D. Michel J.M. Pin J.P. Bockaert J. Fagni L. Neuropharmacology. 1999; 38: 793-803Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). The wild type mGlu7a and chimeric mGlu7/2 receptors were tagged at their N terminus with a Myc epitope, as described previously (27Perroy J. Prézeau L. De Waard M. Shigemoto R. Bockaert J. Fagni L. J. Neurosci. 2000; 20: 7896-7904Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The presence of these Myc-tagged proteins at the cell surface was examined in living (non-permeabilized) cultured neurons. Cells were exposed for 30 min at 37 °C to a polyclonal rabbit anti-Myc (1/300; ABR, Inc.) primary antibody and then rinsed, fixed in a 4% paraformaldehyde, 0.1m glucose-containing phosphate-buffered saline solution, and exposed for 2 h at room temperature to a goat Texas Red-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG (1/1000; Jackson ImmunoResearch). Cells were then rinsed with phosphate-buffered saline and mounted on a glass coverslip for observation on an Axiophot 2 Zeiss microscope. The intensity of Myc immunolabeling was measured on the cell body using the NIH Image program (Wayne Rasband). The ratio of total fluorescence of the cell body area over background (noise) fluorescence was determined in non-saturating conditions of the camera. The fluorescence values were then averaged and compared between neurons transfected with N-Myc-mGlu7a and -mGlu7/2 receptors. We used the whole-cell patch clamp configuration to record Ba2+ current (IBa) from GFP-expressing (mGlu receptor co-transfected) cerebellar granule cells, after 9 ± 1 days in vitro, as described previously (32Ango F.
